Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Jamal Mashburn scored 19 of his 37 points in the first quarter as the Hornets jumped out to a big lead on the New Jersey Nets for the second time in four days, this time easily holding on  for a 104-85 victory.
article.headline: Mashburn scores 27 in first half, finishes with 36

images.name: Mashburn_Jamal 020227 inline
images.caption: Jamal Mashburn had his best game since returning from injury, scoring 36 points.

article.linkText: Mashburn has monster game as Hornets rip Nets
article.story:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) -- Jamal Mashburn is finally feeling good and it couldn't come at a better time for the Charlotte Hornets. Mashburn, in his sixth game back since missing 42 with a strained abdominal muscle, scored a season-high 36 points Wednesday night to lead Charlotte to a 104-85 victory over New Jersey, snapping the Nets' six-game winning streak. "It's hard coming into something midseason, but the toughest part is getting into game shape," Mashburn said. "Nothing you can do prepares you for the bumping and grinding, and sometimes it's going to be ugly trying to get there. But I think I'm getting close." Mashburn was hot early, scoring 19 points in the first quarter en route to 27 at the half. He shot 15-of-20 from the floor in just 32 minutes while helping the Hornets end their three-game losing streak. "I put a lot of pressure on myself to make this a better team," he said. "I don't think I was in a zone, I was just being aggressive." The Hornets are trying desperately to climb into the playoff the race -- they started the night in 10th place in the Eastern Conference, needing to improve two spots to advance to the postseason. Now that Mashburn is back, they're feeling good about their chances. "Mash was just amazing, making shots that he made for me all last year," coach Paul Silas said. "If he can do that and get us on a roll, we should be OK." Mashburn more than carried the load for the other starters -- George Lynch, P.J. Brown and Elden Campbell combined to score eight points -- and took the pressure off injured guard Baron Davis. Davis, playing with a bruised chest, was slow to warm up and took just one shot in the first quarter. He didn't score until a 3-pointer with 9:30 left in the first half and finished with 15 points and 10 assists. "I could tell from the opening tip he had found a rhythm and it helps, because you know all you have to do is pass the ball and get out of his way," said Davis, who described his sternum as "still pretty sore." Jamaal Magloire added 17 and Lee Nailon scored 11 for the Hornets, who avenged their embarrassing 95-93 loss to the Nets on Sunday. Charlotte blew a 23-point second-half lead in that game and missed an opportunity to send it into overtime when Campbell failed to take a wide-open jumper because he thought the Hornets needed a 3 to tie it. "That was a good, old-fashioned butt-kicking right there," New Jersey coach Byron Scott said. "That was a team that was desperate, wanted to win and came out and played like it. Our guys weren't prepared for that kind of physical play and we took it on the chin." The Nets struggled with just about everything and only avoided their worst loss of the season (22 points) because the Hornets emptied their bench with almost five minutes left, allowing every player but Bryce Drew to score. Aaron Williams scored 12 points for New Jersey and Jason Kidd had 12 points, but just six assists. Keith Van Horn added 10. The Nets were outrebounded 45-36, shot just 13-of-24 at the free throw line and had 20 turnovers that led to 25 of Charlotte's points. "They beat us in every aspect of the game -- playing hard, rebounding and basically anything else," Williams said. "They wanted it more than we did, it was evident from the get-go." The Nets couldn't even hit a gimme at the start of the second half. New Jersey opened the third period with Kidd at the line because Davis was called for a technical as he left the court at halftime. Davis vehemently argued a charge called against him with 1.2 seconds to play in the first. Davis went in against Van Horn on a spinning, driving basket, then ripped off his headband when he was called for the foul. He continued to argue until Mashburn stepped in front of him, then, along with Silas, tried to get Davis to leave the court at the end of the period. Kidd missed the technical foul shot anyway. Game notes
Mashburn's 27 first-half points were one short of the franchise record for a half without overtime set by Kelly Tripucka in 1988-89. ... The Hornets did not activate guard David Wesley, who missed his 13th straight game with a broken bone in his foot. He's likely to return Sunday against Detroit. ... The Nets have not won seven straight games since the 1983-84 season. ... The Nets won the season series 3-1 and have swept Charlotte once, winning a three-game series in 1995-96.

statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
